column4: Now I have tried to go http://welcome.opendns.com/ after a restart, but it does not work :\
look into /etc/resolv.conf if it has the nameserver there at all, otherwise you did something wrong probabaly
What should I find in that folder? There is a file called interface-order, maybe it is that?
/etc/resolv.conf is a file, it holds the nameservers used to do dns lookups
look into that to see if wicd actualy applied the dns servers
It doesn't :(
then you did something wrong or maybe wicd crashed or whatever
And it says that I can't edit it
yeah you can only edit it using root priviledges, but be aware of the fact that if you use dhcp it will overwrite the file everytime you request an ip from dhcp
and replace the nameserver with the one supplied by the dhcp server
Sorry, I am not sure that I understand. What do you suggest I could do? In the Wicd options the DNS I typed in is still there, but the resolv.conf shows me the standard DNS
do you use dhcp? if yes change the dns server on your dhcp server
I have no idea what dhcp is
But I found the same bug via Google: http://wicd.sourceforge.net/phpbb/viewtopic.php?f=5&t=226

What if I temporarily removed Wicd and installed network-manager and typed in the OpenDNS. Then I reinstall Wicd (I need it because the GNOME network-manager doesn't work with my laptop's network card)
again if you dont use static ip addresses the dns settings are useless as they will be replaced with the dhcp provided ones
just run gksu gedit /etc/resolv.conf and change the nameservers and see if it works
if they are gone after restarting the connection with wicd you probably use dhcp
Is I requiered to have 3 name servers or can I just have 2?
two is fine
Thank you very much. It worked!
your are welcome
